Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Smart Power Distribution System Curriculum - Multi-Institution Demonstration and Deployment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The steady modernization of electric power distribution systems has included the installation of smart grid enabling technology such as intelligent electronic devices (IED) equipped with their own internal sensors, mini-RTU's (remote terminal units) which measure network flows, and Automatic Meter Reading (AMR) for sensing network loads. While these devices have increased the level of digital control available within power distribution networks, they use varied communication protocols. In addition, significant efforts to increase the amount of renewable and distributed energy sources/storage have been made by state and local governments, yet in some areas, network limits have been reached.

The proposed power distribution system curriculum is designed to educate students in the operation and planning of smart electric power distribution systems. The curriculum centers around a reconfigurable distribution automation and control (RDAC) laboratory coupled with software programs to visualize collected data and to control the distribution system. Project tasks include teaching and lab materials development, implementation and evaluation as well as faculty development.

The project will create mature versions of previous work by making necessary adaptations for implementation and testing at multiple academic institutions. The subsequent evaluation procedure for these enhanced materials will create a process such that new learning materials developed under this project are expected to also yield successful course and laboratory modules that could be widely distributed. The project will contribute to the effort to modernize the curriculum on power distribution system in the nation's universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF DUE#1226126 Collaborative Research: Smart Power Distribution System Curriculum - Multi-Institution Demonstration and Deployment

The major goal was to develop power distribution system curriculum designed to educate students in the operation and planning of smart electric power distribution systems. The curriculum centers around a distribution automation and control laboratory coupled with software programs to visualize collected data and to control the distribution system.

The following universities are participating:

  • Drexel University (DU) - Lead institution,
  • Cornell University (CU),
  • The College of New Jersey (TCNJ),
  • University of North Carolina - Charlotte (UNCC), Washington State University (WSU).

Please See - Figure 1: Implementation of Laboratory Modules at Multiple Academic Institutions 


At Drexel, main objectives included to:

  • Design, develop and adopt course material in advanced electrical load and node injections studies such that students can model/analyze demand response and other electric load curtailment technologies
  • Design, develop and adopt course material in renewable energy system integration within power distribution systems (grid)
  • Enable remote access to the RDAC laboratory to collaborating institutions

As such, major activities included:

  • Software experiment dissemination amongst collaborative universities
  • Hardware development: including:

–  Interconnection boxes for electric consumer loads, dynamic loads, off-the-shelf universal power supplies

–  Interconnection cabling and transfer panels to integrate renewable solar energy systems

–  Solar microgrid experiments

  • Software development:

–  New programming modules for existing Distribution Energy Management System (DEMS) to include broader range of electrical loads and solar microgrids

–  New DEMS platform to enable remote access (instrumentation, network security, measurement and control, user interfaces)

  • Hosted regular outreach to K-12 students specific to power systems
  • Interacted regularly with industry and others institutions (PECO, PPL, US Navy, US Army) subsequently, PIs (Miu, Niebur, Nwankpa) were invited to develop and give the 2016 CIGRE Grid of the Future Symposium, NGN Tutorial – Tools for Microgrid Analysis.

 

Towards this end, significant results include:

  • created and disseminated revised Matlab Simulink experiments based on our RDAC hardware laboratory (lab) parameters.
  • created multiple hardware lab test procedures for repeatable experiment development processes
  • significantly revised loading scenarios in existing software and hardware lab experiments
  • created new hardware lab experiments focusing on solar microgrid experiments (please see Figure 2 for setup)

Please see – Figure 2: Fig. 8: One Line Diagram of the Solar Microgrid with Corresponding Hardware Component Photographs for Reference

 

From a broader perspective we have focused on the following dissemination activities: locally, at Drexel:

  • hosted regular outreach to K-12 students
  • interacted regularly with industry evaluation team and others (PECO, PPL, US Navy, US Army)

 

Internationally, 3 refereed journals have been accepted or appeared and 1 submitted journal paper’s 1st revision is under review. Four (4) refereed conference papers have been accepted or presented. Three (3) panel session organization and/or participation has been arranged at education sessions at international conferences.  Finally, an invited, half-day tutorial was designed and developed by the PIs addressing microgrid analysis (directly including results from this project.)
